ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Some days were asynchronous
Virtual seminar with occasional lectures

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: French grammar, vocabulary, and cultural/literary knowledge.
I learned more about comprehending spoken French and reading French literature.

This course really helped me build a solid foundation. As a course conducted completely in French, FREN 130 helped me develop a mindset that thinks in French, rather than English. This course taught me all of the basic grammar needed to communicate in the language. Prior to this course, I had never read a full-length French novel. I found my reading comprehension improve greatly by taking this course.

I developed my understanding of the French language as well as French culture. I learned how to use the subjunctive and the predicate in French, and how to determine whether or not the imperfect was to be used during if clauses.
Verbal and written skills in French
My knowledge of the French language deeply improved.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The assessments were structured in ways that felt unnecessarily difficult, but a big strength of the course was that whether Madame Devos was teaching or it was Madame Koizim, the classes were engaging and the material was taught well.

The biggest strength of this course was the willingness that the professors had to engage and help students. The course material was time-consuming but I felt that most of the exercises were important either for improving grammar or for understanding the current reading assignment. A notable weakness is the lack of speaking exercises which could be improved upon by including assignments that required students to speak with other students or the professors.

I think that the department needs to include more literature from around the Francophone world, not just France. This course also was very heavy, with each of the works we studied dealing with death except for Le Petit Nicolas. While the French are often macabre, I think that for an intermediate to Advanced course such as this, it was a bit too heavy. I also think that there was not enough that focused on people of color. The closest we got to that was Monsieur Ibrahim and the "Arabes" in L'tranger.

The language learning method was great for me, working on the course every day is very helpful in developing and maintaining language skills, and it is clear the method has been meticulously put together. The professor was engaging and understanding. The core weakness for this course is the lack of diversity in its curriculum, I would have loved a more diverse selection of reading and watching, the majority of which was by and about white men. Because this is a language class, there is not much time and space to address the racism and sexism in some of the material (esp. L'Etranger and Jules et Jim) (and it may not be the right place to do so anyway).

The course is very well geared to fortifying the concepts from L1 and L2 French. I was appreciative of the flexibility of the teachers, particularly considering the circumstances of this semester. I think the biggest area to improve is the specific literature we engaged with. I felt as though some of the literature felt a bit dated and could have been changed with more contemporary options. I would appreciate a balance of the two, particularly when some of these engage with social issues, it would be nice to see some more up-to-date content.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed the asynchronous learning environments since this class is such a large investment (time-wise). I liked the powerpoints to explain grammatical concepts as well as games in order to fully understand the vocab
The mix of lecture and seminar, and the use of breakout rooms was very helpful. The occasional asynchronous session was also great.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it is a highly effective way to improve French abilities.
If you have an interest In reading French literature and learning some more complex grammar techniques, sure. Be prepared to learn a lot of vocab.

I would recommend this course. Although it may appear daunting, the course is well worth the time and energy required to do well. I took French throughout middle and high school but I felt that I learned more in one semester taking FREN 130 than I did all of the six years I took French prior to coming to Yale. However, if you have other classes that require a significant time commitment, then you might want to reconsider.
Yes because I do think that my French skills improved. I would recommend having enough time to fully dive into exercises to anyone considering the course.
Yes, the method of learning was very helpful and I feel like I've improved my language skills.
I would recommend this course as long as some of the material is changed.
